title: Heteroscedasticity
text: OLS estimators regression predictions based remains unbiased consistent. OLS estimators longer BLUE (Best Linear Unbiased Estimators) longer efficient, regression predictions inefficient . inconsistency covariance matrix estimated regression coefficients, tests hypotheses, (t-test, F-test) longer valid. olsrr provides following 4 tests detecting heteroscedasticity: Bartlett Test Breusch Pagan Test Score Test F Test

title: Heteroscedasticity
text: Bartlett’s test used test variances across samples equal. sensitive departures normality. Levene test alternative test less sensitive departures normality. can perform test using 2 continuous variables, one continuous one grouping variable, formula linear model.

title: Heteroscedasticity
code: ols_test_bartlett(hsb, 'read', group_var = 'female') ##  ##     Bartlett's Test of Homogenity of Variances     ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Ho: Variances are equal across groups ## Ha: Variances are unequal for atleast two groups ##  ##         Test Summary          ##  ---------------------------- ##  DF            =    1  ##  Chi2          =    0.1866579  ##  Prob > Chi2   =    0.6657129

title: Heteroscedasticity
code: ols_test_bartlett(hsb, 'read', 'write') ##  ##     Bartlett's Test of Homogenity of Variances     ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Ho: Variances are equal across groups ## Ha: Variances are unequal for atleast two groups ##  ##         Data           ##  --------------------- ##  Variables: read write  ##  ##         Test Summary          ##  ---------------------------- ##  DF            =    1  ##  Chi2          =    1.222871  ##  Prob > Chi2   =    0.2687979

title: Heteroscedasticity
text: Breusch Pagan Test introduced Trevor Breusch Adrian Pagan 1979. used test heteroskedasticity linear regression model assumes error terms normally distributed. tests whether variance errors regression dependent values independent variables. \(\chi^{2}\) test. can perform test using fitted values model, predictors model subset independent variables. includes options perform multiple tests p value adjustments. options p value adjustments include Bonferroni, Sidak Holm’s method.

what: Use fitted values of the model
title: Heteroscedasticity
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + drat, data = mtcars) ols_test_breusch_pagan(model) ##  ##  Breusch Pagan Test for Heteroskedasticity ##  ----------------------------------------- ##  Ho: the variance is constant             ##  Ha: the variance is not constant         ##  ##              Data                ##  ------------------------------- ##  Response : mpg  ##  Variables: fitted values of mpg  ##  ##        Test Summary          ##  --------------------------- ##  DF            =    1  ##  Chi2          =    1.429672  ##  Prob > Chi2   =    0.231818

what: Use independent variables of the model
title: Heteroscedasticity
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + drat, data = mtcars) ols_test_breusch_pagan(model, rhs = TRUE) ##  ##  Breusch Pagan Test for Heteroskedasticity ##  ----------------------------------------- ##  Ho: the variance is constant             ##  Ha: the variance is not constant         ##  ##            Data             ##  -------------------------- ##  Response : mpg  ##  Variables: disp hp wt drat  ##  ##         Test Summary          ##  ---------------------------- ##  DF            =    4  ##  Chi2          =    1.513808  ##  Prob > Chi2   =    0.8241927

title: Measures of Influence
text: possible single observation great influence results regression analysis. therefore important detect influential observations take consideration interpreting results. olsrr offers following tools detect influential observations: Cook’s D Bar Plot Cook’s D Chart DFBETAs Panel DFFITs Plot Studentized Residual Plot Standardized Residual Chart Studentized Residuals vs Leverage Plot Deleted Studentized Residual vs Fitted Values Plot Hadi Plot Potential Residual Plot

title: Measures of Influence
text: Bar Plot Cook’s distance detect observations strongly influence fitted values model. Cook’s distance introduced American statistician R Dennis Cook 1977. used identify influential data points. depends residual leverage .e takes account x value y value observation. Steps compute Cook’s distance: delete observations one time. refit regression model remaining \((n - 1)\) observations examine much fitted values change ith observation deleted. data point large cook’s d indicates data point strongly influences fitted values.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_plot_cooksd_bar(model)

title: Measures of Influence
text: Chart Cook’s distance detect observations strongly influence fitted values model.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_plot_cooksd_chart(model)

title: Measures of Influence
text: DFBETA measures difference parameter estimate without influential point. DFBETA data point .e n observations k variables, \(n * k\) DFBETAs. general, large values DFBETAS indicate observations influential estimating given parameter. Belsley, Kuh, Welsch recommend 2 general cutoff value indicate influential observations \(\frac{2}{\sqrt{n}}\) size-adjusted cutoff.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt, data = mtcars) ols_plot_dfbetas(model)

title: Measures of Influence
text: Proposed Welsch Kuh (1977). scaled difference \(^{th}\) fitted value obtained full data \(^{th}\) fitted value obtained deleting \(^{th}\) observation. DFFIT - difference fits, used identify influential data points. quantifies number standard deviations fitted value changes ith data point omitted. Steps compute DFFITs: delete observations one time. refit regression model remaining observations examine much fitted values change ith observation deleted. observation deemed influential absolute value DFFITS value greater : \[{2}*\sqrt{\frac{(p + 1)}{(n - p - 1)}}\] size-adjusted cutoff recommended Belsley, Kuh, Welsch \[{2}*\sqrt{\frac{p}{n}}\] n number observations p number predictors including intercept. olsrr uses size adjusted cutoff default.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_plot_dffits(model)

title: Measures of Influence

code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_plot_resid_stud(model)

title: Collinearity Diagnostics, Model Fit & Variable Contribution
text: Collinearity implies two variables near perfect linear combinations one another. Multicollinearity involves two variables. presence multicollinearity, regression estimates unstable high standard errors.

title: Collinearity Diagnostics, Model Fit & Variable Contribution
text: Variance inflation factors measure inflation variances parameter estimates due collinearities exist among predictors. measure much variance estimated regression coefficient \(\beta_{k}\) “inflated” existence correlation among predictor variables model. VIF 1 means correlation among kth predictor remaining predictor variables, hence variance \(\beta_{k}\) inflated . general rule thumb VIFs exceeding 4 warrant investigation, VIFs exceeding 10 signs serious multicollinearity requiring correction. Steps calculate VIF: Regress \(k^{th}\) predictor rest predictors model. Compute \({R}^{2}_{k}\) \[VIF = \frac{1}{1 - {R}^{2}_{k}} = \frac{1}{Tolerance}\]
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_vif_tol(model) ##   Variables Tolerance      VIF ## 1      disp 0.1252279 7.985439 ## 2        hp 0.1935450 5.166758 ## 3        wt 0.1445726 6.916942 ## 4      qsec 0.3191708 3.133119

title: Collinearity Diagnostics, Model Fit & Variable Contribution
text: Percent variance predictor accounted predictors. Steps calculate tolerance: Regress \(k^{th}\) predictor rest predictors model. Compute \({R}^{2}_{k}\) \[Tolerance = 1 - {R}^{2}_{k}\]

title: Collinearity Diagnostics, Model Fit & Variable Contribution
text: Added variable plot provides information marginal importance predictor variable \(X_{k}\), given predictor variables already model. shows marginal importance variable reducing residual variability. added variable plot introduced Mosteller Tukey (1977). enables us visualize regression coefficient new variable considered included model. plot can constructed predictor variable. Let us assume want test effect adding/removing variable X model. Let response variable model Y Steps construct added variable plot: Regress Y variables X store residuals (Y residuals). Regress X variables included model (X residuals). Construct scatter plot Y residuals X residuals. Y X residuals represent? Y residuals represent part Y explained variables X. X residuals represent part X explained variables. slope line fitted points added variable plot equal regression coefficient Y regressed variables including X. strong linear relationship added variable plot indicates increased importance contribution X model already containing predictors.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_plot_added_variable(model) ## `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ## `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ## `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ## `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Collinearity Diagnostics, Model Fit & Variable Contribution
text: residual plus component plot introduced Ezekeil (1924). called Partial Residual Plot Larsen McCleary (1972). Hadi Chatterjee (2012) called residual plus component plot. Steps construct plot: Regress Y variables including X store residuals (e). Multiply e regression coefficient X (eX). Construct scatter plot eX X residual plus component plot indicates whether non-linearity present relationship Y X can suggest possible transformations linearizing data.

title: Residual Diagnostics
text: olsrr offers tools detecting violation standard regression assumptions. take look residual diagnostics. standard regression assumptions include following residuals/errors: error normal distribution (normality assumption). errors mean zero. errors unknown variance (homoscedasticity assumption). error independent (independent errors assumption).

title: Residual Diagnostics
text: Graph detecting violation normality assumption.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_plot_resid_qq(model)

title: Residual Diagnostics
text: Test detecting violation normality assumption. Correlation observed residuals expected residuals normality.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_test_normality(model) ## ----------------------------------------------- ##        Test             Statistic       pvalue   ## ----------------------------------------------- ## Shapiro-Wilk              0.9366         0.0600  ## Kolmogorov-Smirnov        0.1152         0.7464  ## Cramer-von Mises          2.8122         0.0000  ## Anderson-Darling          0.5859         0.1188  ## ----------------------------------------------- model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_test_correlation(model) ## [1] 0.970066

title: Residual Diagnostics
text: scatter plot residuals y axis fitted values x axis detect non-linearity, unequal error variances, outliers. Characteristics well behaved residual vs fitted plot: residuals spread randomly around 0 line indicating relationship linear. residuals form approximate horizontal band around 0 line indicating homogeneity error variance. one residual visibly away random pattern residuals indicating outliers.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_plot_resid_fit(model)

code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_plot_resid_hist(model)

title: Akaike information criterion — ols_aic
text: model object class lm. method character vector; specify method compute AIC. Valid options include R, STATA SAS. corrected Logical; TRUE, returns corrected akaike information criterion SAS method.

title: Akaike information criterion — ols_aic
text: Akaike information criterion model.

title: Akaike information criterion — ols_aic
text: AIC provides means model selection. Given collection models data, AIC estimates quality model, relative models. R STATA use loglikelihood compute AIC. SAS uses residual sum squares. formula case: R & STATA $$AIC = -2(loglikelihood) + 2p$$ SAS $$AIC = n * ln(SSE / n) + 2p$$ corrected $$AIC = n * ln(SSE / n) + ((n * (n + p)) / (n - p - 2))$$ n sample size p number model parameters including intercept.

title: Akaike information criterion — ols_aic
text: Akaike, H. (1969). “Fitting Autoregressive Models Prediction.” Annals Institute Statistical Mathematics 21:243–247. Judge, G. G., Griffiths, W. E., Hill, R. C., Lee, T.-C. (1980). Theory Practice Econometrics. New York: John Wiley & Sons.

code: # using R computation method model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_aic(model) #> [1] 159.0696  # using STATA computation method model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_aic(model, method = 'STATA') #> [1] 157.0696  # using SAS computation method model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_aic(model, method = 'SAS') #> [1] 66.25754  # corrected akaike information criterion model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_aic(model, method = 'SAS', corrected = TRUE) #> [1] 103.6175

title: Collinearity diagnostics — ols_coll_diag
text: Collinearity implies two variables near perfect linear combinations one another. Multicollinearity involves two variables. presence multicollinearity, regression estimates unstable high standard errors. Tolerance Percent variance predictor accounted predictors. Steps calculate tolerance: Regress kth predictor rest predictors model. Compute \(R^2\) - coefficient determination regression step. \(Tolerance = 1 - R^2\) Variance Inflation Factor Variance inflation factors measure inflation variances parameter estimates due collinearities exist among predictors. measure much variance estimated regression coefficient \(\beta_k\)  inflated existence correlation among predictor variables model. VIF 1 means correlation among kth predictor remaining predictor variables, hence variance \(\beta_k\) inflated . general rule thumb VIFs exceeding 4 warrant investigation, VIFs exceeding 10 signs serious multicollinearity requiring correction. Steps calculate VIF: Regress kth predictor rest predictors model. Compute \(R^2\) - coefficient determination regression step. \(Tolerance = 1 / 1 - R^2 = 1 / Tolerance\) Condition Index multivariate statistical approaches involve decomposing correlation matrix linear combinations variables. linear combinations chosen first combination largest possible variance (subject restrictions), second combination next largest variance, subject uncorrelated first, third largest possible variance, subject uncorrelated first second, forth. variance linear combinations called eigenvalue. Collinearity spotted finding 2 variables large proportions variance (.50 ) correspond large condition indices. rule thumb label large condition indices range 30 larger.

title: Collinearity diagnostics — ols_coll_diag
text: Belsley, D. ., Kuh, E., Welsch, R. E. (1980). Regression Diagnostics: Identifying Influential Data Sources Collinearity. New York: John Wiley & Sons.

title: Added variable plots — ols_plot_added_variable
text: added variable plot introduced Mosteller Tukey (1977). enables us visualize regression coefficient new variable considered included model. plot can constructed predictor variable. Let us assume want test effect adding/removing variable X model. Let response variable model Y Steps construct added variable plot: Regress Y variables X store residuals (Y residuals). Regress X variables included model (X residuals). Construct scatter plot Y residuals X residuals. Y X residuals represent? Y residuals represent part Y explained variables X. X residuals represent part X explained variables. slope line fitted points added variable plot equal regression coefficient Y regressed variables including X. strong linear relationship added variable plot indicates increased importance contribution X model already containing predictors.

title: Studentized residual plot data — ols_prep_srplot_data
text: Generates data studentized residual plot.

title: Studentized residual plot data — ols_prep_srplot_data
code: ols_prep_srplot_data(model, threshold = NULL)

title: Studentized residual plot data — ols_prep_srplot_data
text: model object class lm. threshold Threshold detecting outliers. Default 3.

title: PRESS — ols_press
text: PRESS (prediction sum squares) tells well model predict new data.

title: PRESS — ols_press
code: ols_press(model)

title: PRESS — ols_press
text: model object class lm.

title: PRESS — ols_press
text: Predicted sum squares model.

title: PRESS — ols_press
text: prediction sum squares (PRESS) sum squares prediction error. fitted obtain predicted value ith observation. Use PRESS assess model's predictive ability. Usually, smaller PRESS value, better model's predictive ability.

title: PRESS — ols_press
text: Kutner, MH, Nachtscheim CJ, Neter J Li W., 2004, Applied Linear Statistical Models (5th edition). Chicago, IL., McGraw Hill/Irwin.

title: PRESS — ols_press
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_press(model) #> [1] 257.8314

what: Lack of fit F test — ols_pure_error_anova
title: Lack of fit F test — ols_pure_error_anova
text: Assess much error prediction due lack model fit.

title: Lack of fit F test — ols_pure_error_anova
code: ols_pure_error_anova(model, ...)

title: Lack of fit F test — ols_pure_error_anova
text: model object class lm. ... parameters.

title: Lack of fit F test — ols_pure_error_anova
text: ols_pure_error_anova returns object class "ols_pure_error_anova". object class "ols_pure_error_anova" list containing following components: lackoffit lack fit sum squares pure_error pure error sum squares rss regression sum squares ess error sum squares total total sum squares rms regression mean square ems error mean square lms lack fit mean square pms pure error mean square rf f statistic lf lack fit f statistic pr p-value f statistic pl p-value pf lack fit f statistic mpred data.frame containing data response predictor model df_rss regression sum squares degrees freedom df_ess error sum squares degrees freedom df_lof lack fit degrees freedom df_error pure error degrees freedom final data.frame; contains computed values used lack fit f test resp character vector; name response variable preds character vector; name predictor variable

title: Lack of fit F test — ols_pure_error_anova
text: residual sum squares resulting regression can decomposed 2 components: Due lack fit Due random variation error due lack fit just random error, model discarded new model must built.

title: Lack of fit F test — ols_pure_error_anova
text: lack fit F test works simple linear regression. Moreover, important data contains repeat observations .e. replicates least one values predictor x. test generally applies datasets plenty replicates.

title: Lack of fit F test — ols_pure_error_anova
text: Kutner, MH, Nachtscheim CJ, Neter J Li W., 2004, Applied Linear Statistical Models (5th edition). Chicago, IL., McGraw Hill/Irwin.

title: Lack of fit F test — ols_pure_error_anova
Ordinary least squares regression — ols_regress

title: Bayesian information criterion — ols_sbc
text: Bayesian information criterion model selection.

title: Bayesian information criterion — ols_sbc
code: ols_sbc(model, method = c("R", "STATA", "SAS"))

title: Bayesian information criterion — ols_sbc
text: model object class lm. method character vector; specify method compute BIC. Valid options include R, STATA SAS.

title: Bayesian information criterion — ols_sbc
text: bayesian information criterion model.

title: Bayesian information criterion — ols_sbc
text: SBC provides means model selection. Given collection models data, SBC estimates quality model, relative models. R STATA use loglikelihood compute SBC. SAS uses residual sum squares. formula case: R & STATA $$AIC = -2(loglikelihood) + ln(n) * 2p$$ SAS $$AIC = n * ln(SSE / n) + p * ln(n)$$ n sample size p number model parameters including intercept.

title: Bayesian information criterion — ols_sbc
text: Schwarz, G. (1978). “Estimating Dimension Model.” Annals Statistics 6:461–464. Judge, G. G., Griffiths, W. E., Hill, R. C., Lee, T.-C. (1980). Theory Practice Econometrics. New York: John Wiley & Sons.

title: Bayesian information criterion — ols_sbc
code: # using R computation method model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_sbc(model) #> [1] 167.864  # using STATA computation method model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_sbc(model, method = 'STATA') #> [1] 164.3983  # using SAS computation method model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_sbc(model, method = 'SAS') #> [1] 73.58622

title: Sawa's bayesian information criterion — ols_sbic
text: Sawa's bayesian information criterion model selection.

title: Sawa's bayesian information criterion — ols_sbic
code: ols_sbic(model, full_model)

title: Sawa's bayesian information criterion — ols_sbic
text: model object class lm. full_model object class lm.

title: Sawa's bayesian information criterion — ols_sbic
text: Sawa's Bayesian Information Criterion

title: Sawa's bayesian information criterion — ols_sbic
text: Sawa (1978) developed model selection criterion derived Bayesian modification AIC criterion. Sawa's Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) function number observations n, SSE, pure error variance fitting full model, number independent variables including intercept. $$SBIC = n * ln(SSE / n) + 2(p + 2)q - 2(q^2)$$ \(q = n(\sigma^2)/SSE\), n sample size, p number model parameters including intercept SSE residual sum squares.

title: Sawa's bayesian information criterion — ols_sbic
text: Sawa, T. (1978). “Information Criteria Discriminating among Alternative Regression Models.” Econometrica 46:1273–1282. Judge, G. G., Griffiths, W. E., Hill, R. C., Lee, T.-C. (1980). Theory Practice Econometrics. New York: John Wiley & Sons.

title: Sawa's bayesian information criterion — ols_sbic
code: full_model <- lm(mpg ~ ., data = mtcars) model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + qsec, data = mtcars) ols_sbic(model, full_model) #> [1] 70.27599

title: Stepwise R-Squared backward regression — ols_step_backward_r2
code: # stepwise backward regression model <- lm(y ~ ., data = surgical) ols_step_backward_r2(model) #> [1] "No variables have been removed from the model."  # final model and selection metrics k <- ols_step_backward_aic(model) k$metrics #>   step variable        r2    adj_r2      aic      sbc     sbic #> 1    1  alc_mod 0.7817703 0.7485615 734.4068 752.3077 583.8836 #> 2    2   gender 0.7814169 0.7535127 732.4942 748.4061 581.2896 #> 3    3      age 0.7809054 0.7580831 730.6204 744.5433 578.8438 k$model #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = paste(response, "~", paste(preds, collapse = " + ")),  #>     data = l) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)          bcs       pindex  enzyme_test   liver_test    alc_heavy   #>   -1178.330       59.864        8.924        9.748       58.064      317.848   #>   # include or exclude variable # force variables to be included in the selection process ols_step_backward_r2(model, include = c("alc_mod", "gender")) #> [1] "No variables have been removed from the model."  # use index of variable instead of name ols_step_backward_r2(model, include = c(7, 6)) #> [1] "No variables have been removed from the model."  # force variable to be excluded from selection process ols_step_backward_r2(model, exclude = c("alc_heavy", "bcs")) #> [1] "No variables have been removed from the model."  # use index of variable instead of name ols_step_backward_r2(model, exclude = c(8, 1)) #> [1] "No variables have been removed from the model."

code: if (FALSE) { # stepwise regression model <- lm(y ~ ., data = stepdata) ols_step_both_adj_r2(model)  # stepwise regression plot model <- lm(y ~ ., data = stepdata) k <- ols_step_both_adj_r2(model) plot(k)  # selection metrics k$metrics  # final model k$model  # include or exclude variables # force variable to be included in selection process model <- lm(y ~ ., data = stepdata)  ols_step_both_adj_r2(model, include = c("x6"))  # use index of variable instead of name ols_step_both_adj_r2(model, include = c(6))  # force variable to be excluded from selection process ols_step_both_adj_r2(model, exclude = c("x2"))  # use index of variable instead of name ols_step_both_adj_r2(model, exclude = c(2))  # include & exclude variables in the selection process ols_step_both_adj_r2(model, include = c("x6"), exclude = c("x2"))  # use index of variable instead of name ols_step_both_adj_r2(model, include = c(6), exclude = c(2)) }

title: Breusch pagan test — ols_test_breusch_pagan
text: Breusch Pagan Test introduced Trevor Breusch Adrian Pagan 1979. used test heteroskedasticity linear regression model. test whether variance errors regression dependent values independent variable. Null Hypothesis: Equal/constant variances Alternative Hypothesis: Unequal/non-constant variances Computation Fit regression model Regress squared residuals model independent variables Compute \(nR^2\). follows chi square distribution p -1 degrees         freedom, p number independent variables, n sample size 				 \(R^2\) coefficient determination regression step 2.

title: Breusch pagan test — ols_test_breusch_pagan
text: T.S. Breusch & .R. Pagan (1979), Simple Test Heteroscedasticity Random Coefficient Variation. Econometrica 47, 1287–1294 Cook, R. D.; Weisberg, S. (1983). "Diagnostics Heteroskedasticity Regression". Biometrika. 70 (1): 1–10.

title: Breusch pagan test — ols_test_breusch_pagan
code: # model model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt + drat, data = mtcars)  # use fitted values of the model ols_test_breusch_pagan(model) #>  #>  Breusch Pagan Test for Heteroskedasticity #>  ----------------------------------------- #>  Ho: the variance is constant             #>  Ha: the variance is not constant         #>  #>              Data                #>  ------------------------------- #>  Response : mpg  #>  Variables: fitted values of mpg  #>  #>        Test Summary          #>  --------------------------- #>  DF            =    1  #>  Chi2          =    1.429672  #>  Prob > Chi2   =    0.231818   # use independent variables of the model ols_test_breusch_pagan(model, rhs = TRUE) #>  #>  Breusch Pagan Test for Heteroskedasticity #>  ----------------------------------------- #>  Ho: the variance is constant             #>  Ha: the variance is not constant         #>  #>            Data             #>  -------------------------- #>  Response : mpg  #>  Variables: disp hp wt drat  #>  #>         Test Summary          #>  ---------------------------- #>  DF            =    4  #>  Chi2          =    1.513808  #>  Prob > Chi2   =    0.8241927   # use independent variables of the model and perform multiple tests ols_test_breusch_pagan(model, rhs = TRUE, multiple = TRUE) #>  #>  Breusch Pagan Test for Heteroskedasticity #>  ----------------------------------------- #>  Ho: the variance is constant             #>  Ha: the variance is not constant         #>  #>            Data             #>  -------------------------- #>  Response : mpg  #>  Variables: disp hp wt drat  #>  #>         Test Summary (Unadjusted p values)        #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   Variable           chi2       df        p      #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   disp             1.2355345     1    0.2663334  #>   hp               0.9209878     1    0.3372157  #>   wt               1.2529988     1    0.2629805  #>   drat             1.1668486     1    0.2800497  #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   simultaneous     1.5138083     4    0.8241927  #>  ----------------------------------------------  # bonferroni p value adjustment ols_test_breusch_pagan(model, rhs = TRUE, multiple = TRUE, p.adj = 'bonferroni') #>  #>  Breusch Pagan Test for Heteroskedasticity #>  ----------------------------------------- #>  Ho: the variance is constant             #>  Ha: the variance is not constant         #>  #>            Data             #>  -------------------------- #>  Response : mpg  #>  Variables: disp hp wt drat  #>  #>         Test Summary (Bonferroni p values)        #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   Variable           chi2       df        p      #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   disp             1.2355345     1    1.0000000  #>   hp               0.9209878     1    1.0000000  #>   wt               1.2529988     1    1.0000000  #>   drat             1.1668486     1    1.0000000  #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   simultaneous     1.5138083     4    0.8241927  #>  ----------------------------------------------  # sidak p value adjustment ols_test_breusch_pagan(model, rhs = TRUE, multiple = TRUE, p.adj = 'sidak') #>  #>  Breusch Pagan Test for Heteroskedasticity #>  ----------------------------------------- #>  Ho: the variance is constant             #>  Ha: the variance is not constant         #>  #>            Data             #>  -------------------------- #>  Response : mpg  #>  Variables: disp hp wt drat  #>  #>           Test Summary (Sidak p values)           #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   Variable           chi2       df        p      #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   disp             1.2355345     1    0.7102690  #>   hp               0.9209878     1    0.8070305  #>   wt               1.2529988     1    0.7049362  #>   drat             1.1668486     1    0.7313356  #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   simultaneous     1.5138083     4    0.8241927  #>  ----------------------------------------------  # holm's p value adjustment ols_test_breusch_pagan(model, rhs = TRUE, multiple = TRUE, p.adj = 'holm') #>  #>  Breusch Pagan Test for Heteroskedasticity #>  ----------------------------------------- #>  Ho: the variance is constant             #>  Ha: the variance is not constant         #>  #>            Data             #>  -------------------------- #>  Response : mpg  #>  Variables: disp hp wt drat  #>  #>           Test Summary (Holm's p values)          #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   Variable           chi2       df        p      #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   disp             1.2355345     1    0.7990002  #>   hp               0.9209878     1    0.3372157  #>   wt               1.2529988     1    1.0000000  #>   drat             1.1668486     1    0.5600994  #>  ---------------------------------------------- #>   simultaneous     1.5138083     4    0.8241927  #>  ----------------------------------------------

code: # model model <- lm(mpg ~ disp + hp + wt, data = mtcars)  # using fitted values of the model ols_test_score(model) #>  #>  Score Test for Heteroskedasticity #>  --------------------------------- #>  Ho: Variance is homogenous #>  Ha: Variance is not homogenous #>  #>  Variables: fitted values of mpg  #>  #>         Test Summary          #>  ---------------------------- #>  DF            =    1  #>  Chi2          =    0.6452907  #>  Prob > Chi2   =    0.4218014   # using predictors from the model ols_test_score(model, rhs = TRUE) #>  #>  Score Test for Heteroskedasticity #>  --------------------------------- #>  Ho: Variance is homogenous #>  Ha: Variance is not homogenous #>  #>  Variables: disp hp wt  #>  #>         Test Summary          #>  ---------------------------- #>  DF            =    3  #>  Chi2          =    0.945898  #>  Prob > Chi2   =    0.8143398   # specify predictors from the model ols_test_score(model, vars = c('disp', 'wt')) #>  #>  Score Test for Heteroskedasticity #>  --------------------------------- #>  Ho: Variance is homogenous #>  Ha: Variance is not homogenous #>  #>  Variables: disp wt  #>  #>         Test Summary          #>  ---------------------------- #>  DF            =    2  #>  Chi2          =    0.5349726  #>  Prob > Chi2   =    0.7653008
